## Loading of the required libraries

Loaded gridExtra library to display the charts side by side



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pacman:: p_load(tidyverse, gridExtra )
```
:::



## Introducing ggplot



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
exam_data <-read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")
```
:::



### R Graphics VS ggplot



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
par(mfrow = c(1, 3))

His_maths <- hist(exam_data$MATHS)

His_eng <- hist(exam_data$ENGLISH)

His_Sci <- hist(exam_data$SCIENCE)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



### Grammar of Graphics



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data = exam_data)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2: Aesthetic mappings



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
      aes(x=MATHS))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



## Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2: geom

Geometric objects are the actual data marks being ploteed on the chat. Examples include:

![Copied from Prof Kam webpage: https://r4va.netlify.app/chap01#working-with-theme](images/geom_.jpg)

A plot must have at least one geom; there is no upper limit.

You can add a geom to a plot using the + operator. For complete list, please refer to [here.](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/#section-layer-geoms)

### Geometric Objects: geom_bar



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(x=RACE)) + 
  geom_bar()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(x=MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(dotsize=0.5,fill="red")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(x=MATHS)) + 
  geom_dotplot(binwidth = 2.5,
               dotsize = 0.5) +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL, breaks = NULL) 
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
## scale_y_continuous function is used to turn off the y-axis and the breaks = NULL is required to remove the inteval.
```
:::



### Geoetirc Objects: geom_histogram ()

Plotting histogram with bin set to 10, instad of using the default as 30.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
Maths_30 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=MATHS))+
  geom_histogram()

Maths_10 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=MATHS))+
  geom_histogram(binwidth=10)

grid.arrange(Maths_30, Maths_10, ncol=2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



### Modifying a geometric object by changing aes ()



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(x=MATHS,
           fill=GENDER)) +
  geom_histogram(bin=20,
                 color="grey30")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



::: callout-note
#### Reference:

```         
Enter "grDevices::colors()"under console to find out the colours. 

```
:::


### Geometric Objects: geom-density()

Using of geom-density() to computes and plots kernel density estimate, which is a smoothed version of the histogram.

The application of kernel smoothing for probability density estimation, i.e., a non-parametric method to estimate the probability density



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_density() 
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



using the same data as 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
Maths_gender_den <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS, 
           colour = GENDER)) +
  geom_density()



Maths_gender_Hist <-ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(x=MATHS,
           fill=GENDER)) +
  geom_histogram(bin=20,
                 color="grey30")

grid.arrange(Maths_gender_den, Maths_gender_Hist, ncol=2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



### Geometric Objects: geom_boxplot 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS,       
           x= GENDER)) +    
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_violin()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### Geometric Objects: geom_point()



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() 
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
with_jitter<- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +                    
  geom_point(position="jitter", 
             size = 0.5)

no_jitter<- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, 
           x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +                    
  geom_point(position="jitter", 
             size = 0.5)


grid.arrange(with_jitter, no_jitter, ncol=2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



## Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2: stat

The following Sections describe the show the statstictally transformation of data, 

The Statistics functions statistically transform data, usually as some form of summary. For example:

frequency of values of a variable (bar graph)
a mean
a confidence limit
There are two ways to use these functions:
add a stat_() function and override the default geom, or
add a geom_() function and override the default stat.




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




## Working with stat()



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(y = MATHS, x= GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun = "mean",         
               colour ="red",
               size=4)     
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### Best Fit curve on a scatterplot



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(size=0.5)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, 
           y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              linewidth=0.5)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-22-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




### Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2: Facets


## Facet wrap
facet_wrap wraps a 1d sequence of panels into 2d. This is generally a better use of screen space than facet_grid because most displays are roughly rectangular.

The code chunk below plots a trellis plot using facet-wrap().



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_wrap(~ CLASS)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-23-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### facet_grid() function



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20) +
    facet_grid(~ CLASS)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




### Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2: Coordinates



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-26-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


### Changing the y- and x-axis range



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, size=0.5)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x= MATHS, y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



## Essential Grammatical Elements in ggplot2: Themes

Themes control elements of the graph not related to the data. such as background colour, size of fonts, gridlines colour of labels
Built-in themes include: - theme_gray() (default) - theme_bw() - theme_classic()

A list of theme can be found at this link. Each theme element can be conceived of as either a line (e.g. x-axis), a rectangle (e.g. graph background), or text (e.g. axis title).



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_gray()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-29-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



#### Plotting with theme classic


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_classic()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-30-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



### plotting with theme minimal



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal() # minimal effects
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-31-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::



### Plotting with theme bw



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot (data=exam_data, 
        aes(x=RACE))+
  geom_bar()+
  coord_flip() +
  theme_bw() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Races in Exam Data")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex_01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::
